problemStatement.formal: \forall k \geq 1, \forall \delta > 0, \exists N: |A| \geq \delta N \implies A \text{ contains } k\text{-AP}
problemStatement.plain: For any positive integer k and density δ > 0, there exists N such that every subset of {1,...,N} with at least δN elements contains an arithmetic progression of length k.
whyMatters: Multiple proof techniques: regularity, ergodic, Fourier

knownResults.goal: Survey what exists, formalize statement, document gaps

currentState.focus: Completed survey - identified Mathlib has Roth but not full Szemerédi
currentState.nextAction: None - graduated (full proof out of scope)

knowledge.progressSummary: Surveyed Mathlib infrastructure. Roth (k=3) is fully proven via graph regularity. Full Szemerédi (k≥4) requires hypergraph regularity which is not in any proof assistant.
insights: Szemerédi ≠ Van der Waerden: density version is strictly harder than coloring version
Roth proof chain: Roth ← Corners ← Triangle removal ← Graph regularity
k≥4 requires: k-AP ← (k-1)-corners ← Hypergraph removal ← Hypergraph regularity
Hypergraph regularity is the bottleneck - much more complex than graph regularity
nextSteps: DO NOT attempt full proof - multi-month effort
Better targets: quantitative Roth bounds, Behrend construction
